modules.title: 6.1 The <form> Element (Action & Method)
modules.content: The <form> element is the container for all form controls. The action attribute defines the submission URL, and method defines the HTTP verb (GET or POST).
modules.sample: <form action="/process-data" method="POST"> ... </form>

modules.title: 6.2 Text Input & The 'name' Attribute
modules.content: The <input> element with type="text" is the most common input. The name attribute is crucial for associating the input value with a key when data is sent.
modules.sample: <input type="text" name="user_name" />

modules.title: 6.3 <label> for Accessibility (for/id)
modules.content: The <label> tag is required for accessibility. Linking it to an input is done by ensuring the label's for attribute matches the input's id.
modules.sample: <label for="p-id">Product ID:</label> <input type="text" id="p-id" />

modules.title: 6.4 Password Input and Placeholder Hinting
modules.content: Use type="password" to mask input. The placeholder attribute provides a temporary hint to the user about expected input.
modules.sample: <input type="password" placeholder="Min 8 chars" />

modules.title: 6.5 Submitting Forms with <input type="submit">
modules.content: The <input> with type="submit" is the standard form submission button. The button text is defined by the value attribute.
modules.sample: <input type="submit" value="Save Changes" />

modules.title: 6.6 Submitting with <button type="submit">
modules.content: The <button> element with type="submit" is preferred for richer buttons, as it can contain nested HTML like icons or styled text.
modules.sample: <button type="submit"> <span class="icon">✓</span> Register </button>

modules.title: 6.7 The Reset Button (type="reset")
modules.content: The type="reset" button clears all form fields within the parent <form> element, reverting them to their initial or default values.
modules.sample: <input type="reset" value="Clear All" />

modules.title: 6.8 The 'readonly' Attribute
modules.content: The boolean readonly attribute makes an input field non-editable by the user, but its **value is still submitted** with the form data.
modules.sample: <input type="text" value="Fixed User ID" readonly />

modules.title: 6.9 The 'disabled' Attribute
modules.content: The boolean disabled attribute renders the input unusable, and its **value is NOT submitted** with the form data. It also prevents the field from receiving focus.
modules.sample: <input type="text" disabled value="Unavailable" />

modules.title: 6.10 Form Controls Outside <form> (form attribute)
modules.content: A form control can exist outside its <form> element in the HTML structure by using the control's form attribute, which points to the target <form>'s id.
modules.sample: <form id="main-form" >... <input form="main-form" name="external_data" />

modules.title: Did You Know? GET vs. POST Data Exposure
modules.content: Data submitted via the **GET** method is appended to the URL and is therefore easily visible and bookmarked. Data submitted via **POST** is hidden within the HTTP request body, making it mandatory for sensitive data like passwords.

modules.title: Did You Know? Default Submission Method
modules.content: If the <form> element does not specify a method attribute, the default submission method used by all browsers is **GET**.

modules.title: 7.1 Semantic Input Types (email, tel, url)
modules.content: HTML5 semantic input types provide native validation and optimize the user interface, especially on mobile, by showing a specialized keyboard layout (e.g., the '@' key for email).
modules.sample: <input type="email" /> <input type="tel" />

modules.title: 7.2 UI Input Types (date, time, datetime-local)
modules.content: These types leverage the native operating system's UI to provide date and time selection widgets, which improves both accessibility and user experience across devices.
modules.sample: <input type="date" /> <input type="time" />

modules.title: 7.3 Range and Color Pickers
modules.content: The type="range" creates a slider control, useful for selecting a value within a specified min/max range. type="color" displays a native color selection widget.
modules.sample: <input type="range" min="0" /> <input type="color" />

modules.title: 7.4 Number Input (min, max, step)
modules.content: The type="number" accepts only numerical input. It can be constrained using the min, max, and step attributes.
modules.sample: <input type="number" min="1" step="0.5" />

modules.title: 7.5 Checkboxes and Radio Button Grouping
modules.content: **Radio buttons** (type="radio") are mutually exclusive and must share the same name. **Checkboxes** (type="checkbox") allow multiple selections.
modules.sample: <input type="radio" name="choice" /> Option 1

modules.title: 7.6 Multi-line Textarea (<textarea>)
modules.content: The <textarea> element is for large, multi-line text input. Unlike <input>, it is a container, and its default content is placed between the opening and closing tags.
modules.sample: <textarea name="comment" rows="4">Default text here.</textarea>

modules.title: 7.7 Hidden Input (type="hidden")
modules.content: A type="hidden" input is not displayed to the user but is submitted with the form data. It's used for storing metadata, tracking IDs, or security tokens (like CSRF tokens).
modules.sample: <input type="hidden" name="token" value="xyz123" />

modules.title: 7.8 The <select> and <option> Tags
modules.content: The <select> element creates a dropdown list. Each selectable item is an <option>, and the value sent is the option's value attribute.
modules.sample: <select name="city"> <option value="lon">London</option> </select>

modules.title: 7.9 The 'selected' Attribute in <option>
modules.content: The boolean selected attribute is applied to an <option> tag to specify the default option that is visible when the page first loads.
modules.sample: <option value="usd" selected>USD</option>

modules.title: 7.10 UI Input Types (week, month)
modules.content: These specialized inputs allow for selecting an entire week or month. The submitted value is formatted as ISO 8601 (e.g., '2025-W10' for week, or '2025-03' for March).
modules.sample: <input type="week" /> <input type="month" />

modules.title: Did You Know? Checkbox Submission
modules.content: An unchecked checkbox is **not** included in the submitted form data. A checked checkbox submits its defined name and value, or a default value of 'on' if no value is specified.

modules.title: Did You Know? Cross-Browser Date UI
modules.content: The visual appearance (UI) of date, time, and color inputs is entirely dependent on the user's operating system and browser. You cannot style these native widgets reliably with CSS.

modules.title: 8.1 Grouping Controls with <fieldset> and <legend>
modules.content: The <fieldset> element groups related form controls. The <legend> tag provides a caption for the group, significantly improving form organization and accessibility.
modules.sample: <fieldset> <legend>Shipping Address</legend> ... </fieldset>

modules.title: 8.2 File Uploads (type="file")
modules.content: The type="file" input allows users to select files from their local device for upload. It supports the accept attribute to filter file types.
modules.sample: <input type="file" name="document" />

modules.title: 8.3 The 'enctype' Attribute for File Uploads
modules.content: To successfully submit a file, the parent <form> tag must set its enctype attribute to multipart/form-data. This encoding handles large binary file data.
modules.sample: <form method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data"> ... </form>

modules.title: 8.4 File 'accept' Attribute
modules.content: The accept attribute suggests to the browser which file types should be available in the file selection dialog (e.g., image/*, .pdf, or a specific MIME type).
modules.sample: <input type="file" accept=".png, .jpg" />

modules.title: 8.5 Dropdown Groups (<optgroup>)
modules.content: The <optgroup> element is used within a <select> to visually and semantically group related options. It requires a label attribute for the group title.
modules.sample: <select> <optgroup label="Europe">... </select>

modules.title: 8.6 Multiple Select Lists ('multiple' attribute)
modules.content: Adding the boolean multiple attribute to <select> allows users to select more than one <option>. This often changes the control's rendering from a dropdown to a scrollable list box.
modules.sample: <select name="flavors" multiple> ... </select>

modules.title: 8.7 Suggestion Lists (<datalist>)
modules.content: The <datalist> element provides a list of suggested, editable options for an <input>. It is linked using the input's list attribute matching the datalist's id.
modules.sample: <input list="terms" /> <datalist id="terms">...

modules.title: 8.8 Output Tags (<output>)
modules.content: The <output> element is used to display the result of a calculation, typically performed via client-side JavaScript, from input elements.
modules.sample: <output name="sum_result">0</output>

modules.title: 8.9 The 'target' Attribute in Forms
modules.content: The target attribute on the <form> specifies where to display the response after submission (e.g., _blank opens a new tab, or an iframe name).
modules.sample: <form target="_blank" />

modules.title: 8.10 Disabling <fieldset> Groups
modules.content: Applying the disabled attribute to a <fieldset> will disable **all** form controls within that group, preventing them from being used or submitted.
modules.sample: <fieldset disabled> <legend>Disabled Area</legend> ... </fieldset>

modules.title: Did You Know? Server Handles File Deception
modules.content: The accept attribute is merely a hint to the browser. A malicious user can still bypass this client-side restriction. You must **always** validate the file type and content on the server side for security.

modules.title: Did You Know? Multiple Select Usability
modules.content: When using a <select multiple> list, users typically select multiple options by holding down the **Ctrl** (Windows) or **Command** (Mac) key while clicking.

modules.title: 9.1 The 'required' Attribute
modules.content: The boolean required attribute forces the user to provide a value before the form can be submitted. The browser displays a native error message if the field is empty.
modules.sample: <input type="text" name="username" required />

modules.title: 9.2 Constraining Text Length (minlength, maxlength)
modules.content: The minlength sets the minimum number of characters required for submission, and maxlength prevents the user from typing beyond a certain character count.
modules.sample: <textarea minlength="10" maxlength="500"></textarea>

modules.title: 9.3 Input Matching (The 'pattern' Attribute)
modules.content: The pattern attribute uses a JavaScript-style **Regular Expression (Regex)** to define a format that the input value must match. The form cannot submit if the pattern is violated.
modules.sample: <input type="text" pattern="[A-Za-z]{3}" />

modules.title: 9.4 Custom Feedback with the 'title' Attribute
modules.content: When using the pattern attribute, adding a descriptive title attribute provides a custom tooltip or message to the user when the validation fails.
modules.sample: <input pattern="[0-9]{5}" title="Zip code must be 5 digits" />

modules.title: 9.5 Disabling Validation ('novalidate')
modules.content: The boolean novalidate attribute on the <form> tag completely disables all built-in HTML5 client-side validation for that form, allowing submission regardless of field rules.
modules.sample: <form novalidate > ... </form>

modules.title: 9.6 Number Validation (min, max, step)
modules.content: HTML enforces the numerical constraints set by min, max, and step. If the number falls outside the range or doesn't match the step increment, submission is blocked.
modules.sample: <input type="number" max="100" />

modules.title: 9.7 Email and URL Native Validation
modules.content: Inputs with type="email" automatically check for the presence of the '@' symbol and a domain structure. type="url" checks for protocols like 'http://' or 'https://'.
modules.sample: <input type="url" required />

modules.title: 9.8 Validation Pseudoclasses (:valid, :invalid)
modules.content: CSS provides dynamic pseudoclasses like :valid and :invalid. These can be used to style input fields based on their current validation status (e.g., changing the border color to green or red).
modules.sample: input:invalid { border-color: red; }

modules.title: 9.9 The 'formnovalidate' Attribute
modules.content: The boolean formnovalidate attribute is placed on a specific submit button. It overrides the form's default validation settings, allowing that specific button to submit the form even if validation fails.
modules.sample: <button type="submit" formnovalidate>Save Draft</button>

modules.title: 9.10 Checking Validity with JavaScript (checkValidity)
modules.content: In JavaScript, the checkValidity() method on an input element returns a boolean indicating whether the element satisfies its HTML5 validation constraints. This is often used before processing data.
modules.sample: let valid = document.getElementById('my-input').checkValidity();

modules.title: Did You Know? Client vs. Server Validation
modules.content: HTML5 **client-side validation** is only for UX. It can be bypassed by anyone. **Server-side validation** is mandatory for all security, data integrity, and business rule checks, as it is the last line of defense.

modules.title: Did You Know? Regex Implies Anchors
modules.content: In the HTML pattern attribute, the Regular Expression is implicitly anchored to match the entire input string (as if surrounded by ^ and $). You do not need to add these anchor characters yourself.

modules.title: 10.1 The 'autofocus' Attribute
modules.content: The boolean autofocus attribute automatically places the cursor in the specified form field when the page loads, improving user experience for primary interaction fields (e.g., a search box).
modules.sample: <input type="search" autofocus />

modules.title: 10.2 The 'autocomplete' Attribute (on/off)
modules.content: The autocomplete attribute controls whether the browser should provide predictive text suggestions based on user history. It can be set to on or off on the <form> or individual inputs.
modules.sample: <input type="text" autocomplete="off" />

modules.title: 10.3 Specific Autocomplete Values (e.g., name, email)
modules.content: For improved user experience, you can provide specific `autocomplete` tokens (e.g., `current-password`, `cc-number`, `name`) to help the browser and password managers suggest the correct, previously saved information.
modules.sample: <input type="text" autocomplete="email" />

modules.title: 10.4 The 'multiple' Attribute for Email and File
modules.content: The boolean multiple attribute can be used on type="email" to allow a comma-separated list of emails, or on type="file" to allow selecting multiple files at once.
modules.sample: <input type="file" multiple />

modules.title: 10.5 The 'inputmode' Attribute
modules.content: The inputmode attribute is a hint to the browser about the type of data expected, specifically to display the most appropriate virtual keyboard on mobile devices (e.g., numeric for a calculator pad, or decimal).
modules.sample: <input type="text" inputmode="numeric" />

modules.title: 10.6 Controlling Tab Order ('tabindex')
modules.content: The tabindex attribute can be used to control the sequential order in which form elements receive focus when the user presses the 'Tab' key. A value of -1 removes an element from the tab order.
modules.sample: <input tabindex="2" /> <input tabindex="1" />

modules.title: 10.7 Form Method Overrides (formmethod)
modules.content: The formmethod attribute on a submit button overrides the HTTP method (GET/POST) specified on the parent <form> for that specific submission.
modules.sample: <form method="POST"> <button formmethod="GET">Search</button> </form>

modules.title: 10.8 Overriding Form Action (formaction)
modules.content: Similar to formmethod, the formaction attribute on a submit button overrides the form's action URL, allowing one form to submit data to multiple different endpoints.
modules.sample: <button formaction="/save-draft">Draft</button>

modules.title: 10.9 Using Hidden Inputs for Security Tokens
modules.content: A common security practice is to embed a non-visible Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) token inside a type="hidden" input to protect against unauthorized malicious form submissions.
modules.sample: <input type="hidden" name="csrf_token" />

modules.title: 10.10 The 'formtarget' Attribute
modules.content: The formtarget attribute on a submit button overrides the form's target attribute, allowing one button to submit the form response to a new window while another submits to the current one.
modules.sample: <button formtarget="_blank">Preview in New Tab</button>

modules.title: Did You Know? Autofill Heuristics
modules.content: Some browsers/password managers ignore autocomplete="off" on password fields because users prefer having their credentials saved. To truly prevent autofill, you must use complex or dummy values for the name and id attributes.

modules.title: Did You Know? Multiple Autofocus
modules.content: Only one form element can have the autofocus attribute per page. If multiple elements have it, the browser will ignore all but the last one encountered in the document's structure.

modules.title: 11.1 The <details> and <summary> Tags
modules.content: The <details> element creates a disclosure widget from which information can be retrieved. The <summary> element provides the visible heading for the widget.
modules.sample: <details> <summary>Click to see FAQ</summary> <p>The answer is here.</p> </details>

modules.title: 11.2 The 'open' Attribute in <details>
modules.content: The boolean open attribute on the <details> element determines the default state. If present, the content is visible when the page loads; otherwise, it is collapsed.
modules.sample: <details open> <summary>Initial View</summary> ... </details>

modules.title: 11.3 Meter and Progress Bars (<meter>, <progress>)
modules.content: The <meter> element represents a scalar measurement within a known range (e.g., disk usage). The <progress> element represents the completion status of a task.
modules.sample: <meter min="0" max="100" value="75"></meter> <progress value="50" max="100"></progress>

modules.title: 11.4 <meter> Attributes (low, high, optimum)
modules.content: The <meter> tag uses low, high, and optimum to visually categorize its current value, often affecting the color of the bar (e.g., yellow for low/high, green for optimum).
modules.sample: <meter value="90" high="80" optimum="50"></meter>

modules.title: 11.5 The <template> Tag (Client-Side Content)
modules.content: The <template> element is a container for HTML content that is held client-side but is **not rendered** when the page loads. It is used as a reusable content fragment, typically manipulated and inserted into the DOM using JavaScript.
modules.sample: <template id="user-card"> <div class="card">...</div> </template>

modules.title: 11.6 The <slot> Tag (Web Components)
modules.content: The <slot> element is a placeholder within a web component's Shadow DOM. It defines where user-provided content should be injected into the component's internal structure.
modules.sample: <custom-card> <h3 slot="header">Custom Title</h3> </custom-card>

modules.title: 11.7 The <canvas> Tag (2D/3D Graphics)
modules.content: The <canvas> element provides a drawing surface for rendering 2D shapes, complex charts, or 3D graphics (using WebGL). All drawing operations must be done via JavaScript.
modules.sample: <canvas id="myCanvas" width="400" height="200"> Fallback text. </canvas>

modules.title: 11.8 The <mark> Tag (Highlighting)
modules.content: The <mark> element is used to highlight or mark text that is of particular relevance in the context of a surrounding passage (e.g., search results).
modules.sample: The search term <mark>HTML</mark> was found on this page.

modules.title: 11.9 The <small> Tag (Side Comments)
modules.content: The <small> element represents side comments, fine print, copyright, or legal notices. It is purely semantic and does not imply a reduction in font size for visual style.
modules.sample: <p>Product details.<small>Pricing subject to change.</small></p>

modules.title: 11.10 The <wbr> Tag (Word Break Opportunity)
modules.content: The <wbr> (Word Break Opportunity) element suggests a position within text where the browser may optionally break a line if the original word is too long to prevent overflow.
modules.sample: supercalifragilisticexpiali<wbr>docious

modules.title: Did You Know? <canvas> Fallback
modules.content: The content placed between the opening and closing <canvas> tags is fallback content. It is displayed only if the user's browser does not support the Canvas API.

modules.title: Did You Know? <details> Animation
modules.content: The opening and closing of the native <details> element is usually not animated. Achieving a smooth sliding animation requires the use of JavaScript or complex CSS animation techniques.

modules.title: 12.1 Custom Data Attributes (data-*)
modules.content: Custom data attributes (prefixed with data-) allow you to embed custom, non-visible data into HTML elements. This data can be easily accessed and manipulated using JavaScript (via the dataset property).
modules.sample: <div data-user-id="459" data-is-active="true">User Info</div>

modules.title: 12.2 Accessing Data Attributes in JavaScript
modules.content: In JavaScript, data attributes are accessed using the dataset property, which converts dash-separated names (e.g., data-user-id) to camelCase properties (e.g., dataset.userId).
modules.sample: let el = getElementById('id'); let id = el.dataset.userId;

modules.title: 12.3 Styling with Data Attributes in CSS
modules.content: You can use CSS attribute selectors to style elements based on the presence or value of a data attribute (e.g., [data-is-active="true"]). This is a powerful technique for styling state.
modules.sample: [data-is-active="true"] { border: 2px solid green; }

modules.title: 12.4 The <time> Tag
modules.content: The <time> element is a semantic way to represent dates, times, or durations. The machine-readable version is provided by the datetime attribute, which improves SEO and accessibility.
modules.sample: <time datetime="2025-05-15">May 15th</time>

modules.title: 12.5 The <figcaption> Tag
modules.content: The <figcaption> tag provides a caption or legend for the content of its parent <figure> element, commonly used for images, diagrams, or code blocks.
modules.sample: <figure> <img src="chart.png" /> <figcaption>Sales trends, 2024.</figcaption> </figure>

modules.title: 12.6 The <abbr> Tag and 'title' Attribute
modules.content: The <abbr> element is used to mark up an abbreviation or acronym. The full expansion of the abbreviation is provided in the title attribute, which appears as a tooltip on hover.
modules.sample: <abbr title="World Wide Web">WWW</abbr>

modules.title: 12.7 <iframe> for Embedded Content
modules.content: The <iframe> (Inline Frame) element is used to embed another HTML document (from the same or a different domain) within the current document. It's commonly used for embedding maps, videos, or third-party widgets.
modules.sample: <iframe src="/external-page.html" width="600" height="400"></iframe>

modules.title: 12.8 <iframe> Security (sandbox attribute)
modules.content: The sandbox attribute on an <iframe> applies severe security restrictions (like preventing script execution) to the embedded content, especially useful when embedding untrusted third-party content.
modules.sample: <iframe src="untrusted-ad.html" sandbox></iframe>

modules.title: 12.9 The 'loading' Attribute for Images
modules.content: The loading="lazy" attribute on <img> and <iframe> tells the browser to defer loading the resource until it is near the viewport, significantly improving initial page load performance.
modules.sample: <img src="footer-logo.png" loading="lazy" />

modules.title: 12.10 The 'translate' Attribute
modules.content: The translate="no" attribute is a hint to translation systems (like Google Translate) to prevent them from altering the content, which is crucial for code snippets, brand names, or specific jargon.
modules.sample: <code translate="no">data-attr-name</code>

modules.title: Did You Know? The <bdi> Tag
modules.content: The <bdi> (Bi-Directional Isolation) element is used to specify a portion of text that should be isolated from its surrounding text for the purposes of bi-directional text formatting (e.g., mixing Arabic or Hebrew with English).

modules.title: Did You Know? Data Attribute Performance
modules.content: While useful, avoid storing large chunks of data (like entire JSON objects) in data- attributes. This adds to the size of the DOM, increasing memory consumption and slowing down processing, especially on mobile devices.

modules.title: 13.1 The <dialog> Element (Modal Popups)
modules.content: The <dialog> element provides a native, semantic way to create modal dialogs or popups. It is hidden by default and is typically controlled using JavaScript methods like showModal().
modules.sample: <dialog id="my-dialog"> <p>This is the modal content.</p> </dialog>

modules.title: 13.2 Controlling <dialog> with JavaScript
modules.content: The <dialog> has three key methods: show() (non-modal, does not block interaction), showModal() (modal, blocks interaction), and close().
modules.sample: document.getElementById('my-dialog').showModal();

modules.title: 13.3 Submitting a <dialog> with a Form
modules.content: When a form within a <dialog> uses a button with method="dialog", the dialog closes upon submission without submitting the form data to the server. The button's value is set as the dialog's returnValue.
modules.sample: <button value="cancel" formmethod="dialog">Cancel</button>

modules.title: 13.4 The ::backdrop Pseudoelement
modules.content: When showModal() is used, the browser creates a semi-transparent layer over the rest of the page. This layer can be styled using the ::backdrop pseudoelement.
modules.sample: dialog::backdrop { background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.75); }

modules.title: 13.5 Client-Side Storage: localStorage
modules.content: The localStorage API allows web applications to store up to 5MB of key/value pairs locally in the user's browser, persisting across sessions. It only stores strings.
modules.sample: localStorage.setItem('theme', 'dark'); let theme = localStorage.getItem('theme');

modules.title: 13.6 Client-Side Storage: sessionStorage
modules.content: The sessionStorage API is similar to localStorage but only persists for the duration of the current session (i.e., until the tab or window is closed). It's ideal for temporary data like user preferences or cart contents.
modules.sample: sessionStorage.setItem('cart-id', '109'); sessionStorage.removeItem('cart-id');

modules.title: 13.7 The <picture> Tag (Responsive Images)
modules.content: The <picture> element is used to provide multiple sources (using <source> tags) for an image, allowing the browser to select the most appropriate one based on screen size (media query) or device resolution.
modules.sample: <picture> <source media="(min-width: 600px)" srcset="large.jpg"> <img src="small.jpg" /> </picture>

modules.title: 13.8 <source> 'type' Attribute for Formats
modules.content: The <source> tag within <picture> can use the type attribute to provide different image formats (e.g., modern WebP vs. traditional JPEG), allowing the browser to use the most efficient format it supports.
modules.sample: <source type="image/webp" srcset="img.webp">

modules.title: 13.9 The <address> Tag
modules.content: The <address> element is used to provide contact information (person, company, or organization) for the nearest <article> or the entire document <body>.
modules.sample: <address> Written by Jane Doe.<br> Email: <a href="mailto:jdoe@example.com">jdoe@example.com</a> </address>

modules.title: 13.10 Using <cite> for Titles
modules.content: The <cite> element is used to refer to the title of a creative work (e.g., a book, song, film, or sculpture). By default, most browsers render this text in italics.
modules.sample: <p>The film <cite>Casablanca</cite> is a classic.</p>

modules.title: Did You Know? <dialog> and the Esc Key
modules.content: One of the key benefits of using the native <dialog> element with showModal() is that it automatically handles closing the modal when the user presses the **Escape** key, which is a significant accessibility win.

modules.title: Did You Know? localStorage Security
modules.content: Because localStorage is accessible via JavaScript, it is vulnerable to **Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)** attacks. Therefore, it should **never** be used to store sensitive user data like passwords, session IDs, or security tokens.
